The Glass House in Chislehurst, south east London suburb of Chislehurst, was built in 1951 to accoaccomodate civil servants in the event of a nuclear winter. The property was designed and built specifically for government officials in the event of a nuclear winter. It was chosen because the wooden area surrounding the building afforded it secrecy. The building fell into disrepair in the years following the end of the Cold War.

YouTube user Elman511 cracked open an over-sized egg that was laid by his hens. He found a standard-sized egg inside, along with yolk and white. The unusual occurrence is down to a counter-peristalsis contraction. This is when a second oocyte is released by the hen's ovary before the first egg has completely traveled through the oviduct. This causes the second oocyte to travel down the oviduct and become covered in a shell, creating a giant egg around the first one.

Its incredible slope, which has a gradient of 6.1 per cent on the Shimane Prefecture side and 5.1 per cent on the Tottori Prefecture side, gives it a rollercoaster-like appearance.

Some owners of Apple Watch have found the timepiece's sensors malfunction. Some dark, vibrant ink seems to cause the watch's heart rate monitor to lose connection. This causes the watch's heart rate monitor to lose connection. This is because the sensor reads a pulse by measuring light absorption through the skin. It is thought red and green inks reflect light in a similar way to the tattoos. This in turn leads the watch to think it has stopped making contact with the skin.
Automated Planet Finder (APF) is a 2.4-metre automated telescope. It consists of a 2.4-metre automated telescope and a high-resolution spectrograph. It splits starlight into a rainbow of colours, splitting it into a spectrum of thousands of different wavelengths. The robot observes nearby stars for months, in search of rocky planets.

Named Hyperion is one of Saturn's outer moons, measuring 255 by 161 miles (410 by 260km) The moon's porous surface can be seen in incredible detail in this image taken by Cassini. It's odd appearance is attributed to its low density for its size. This means it is composed largely of water ice with only a small amount of rock.

The USA Freedom Act would codify President Barack Obama's proposal to end the NSA's collection of domestic calling records. The authority to collect those records and other related surveillance provisions of the Patriot Act. The bill would result in phone companies, not the NSA, collecting so-called'metadata' on trillions of phone calls. The measure faces an uncertain future in the Senate, where Mitch McConnell is sponsoring his own bill to extend the PATRIOT Act until 2020.

Fossils from an extinct pygmy sperm whale that died seven million years ago. The skulls of two individuals were unearthed at a sea cliff in Panama. They indicate that the organ involved in sound generation and echolocation got smaller throughout the whale's evolution. The find will help experts fill in gaps in the evolution of cetaceaceans.

US researchers claim that exact prices of goods on eBay attract higher offers than round numbers. Items with precise prices attract higher offers than those with round numbers. Sellers who end their price with '00' typically receive offers that are five to eight per cent lower than those with more specific prices.

'Marilyn Einstein' was created by superimposing a blurry picture of Marilyn Monroe over a picture of Albert Einstein. Features with high spatial frequency (Einstein) are only visible when you're viewing them close up. Those with low spatial frequencies (Monroe) are only visible from further away. Combining pictures of the two produces a single image which changes when the viewer moves closer or farther away from the screen.

Saturday's total lunar eclipse will be visible in North America, Asia and Australia. The event, which is the third in a series of four blood moons, is predicted in the Bible. Scientists at the University of Connecticut say we know how far away the source of a sound is by listening to the echoes it produces. They found that the reverberations of sound helps us locate the distance of a car passing round a bend or a person nearby. The research was conducted by scientists from the University of Connecticut and published in the Journal of Neuroscience. They said that echoes and fluctuations in volume are the cues we use to figure out the distance between us and the source of a noise.

For the first time in 65 years the California Department of Water Resources has found no snow during its manual survey of the land at 6,800 feet in the Sierra Nevada in early April. Scientists funded by Cancer Research UK studied samples taken from tumours in the prostate and around the body. DNA revealed details of how the cancer metastasises, or spreads. It seems that most of the cells in a tumour stay where they are, but a small number have the ability to travel through the body. These cells are the ‘root’ of the cancer and for a treatment to work, they should be destroyed.

Researchers at Joint Base Lewis-McChord in Tacoma, Washington, found no direct link between deployment to a war zone and elevated suicide rates. Military suicides may be more likely after members leave the service than during active duty deployment. The four-year study, the largest of its kind, was published Wednesday in the Journal of American Medicine Association Psychiatry.

A Reading University researcher has said that bees prefer cities to fields. The expansion of farmland has been damaging to bee population. For example, heaths and meadows near Milton Keynes now boast more species of bee than sites in more rural areas. The study said warmer springs can change the life cycles of bees. This can throw them out of sync with the plants they pollinate.

Greenstone is a small egg-shaped device that acts like a beacon, or a beacon. It helps messages move around so-called wireless mesh networks more easily. It was created by developers at Open Garden. It uses a feature that launched in iOS 7 called Multipeer Connectivity Framework. This lets users send messages to people in close proximity that are in Bluetooth or Wi-Fi Direct.

One-Touch-911 app was designed by researchers at Boston-based MIT. It works with emergency dispatchers in 135 countries. Each of the four buttons trigger a standard call to dispatchers. Each call is placed with the phone's GPS location, user details and any pre-entered medical information attached. If the user doesn't have signal, the app lets them 'roam' onto another network to connect the call.

Researchers in Tokyo found that rats flatten their ears and narrow their eyes when they are in pain. They also puff up their cheeks when they are in pain. To test the rodents' response to rats' pained expressions, they showed them the photos in a specially made cage. They found that rats spent less time in the room showing rodents in pain than they did in the other compartment showing rats with neutral expressions.

Research on infants' brains by doctors from Oxford University has found that young babies are more sensitive to pain than adults. It overturns the medical consensus that newborns have a high pain pain threshold. Until now doctors have assumed that the brains of very young babies are not developed enough to feel pain. But the new findings suggest that not only do babies feel pain, but their pain thresholds are even lower than those of adults.

Scientists at UCLA examined the brains of 90 women, 44 of whom took the Pill. They found the lateral orbitofrontal cortex and the posterior cigulate cortex were thinner in those women taking the Pill. The lateral orbitofrontal cortex plays an important role in regulating a person's emotions and their response to rewards. The posterior cingulate cortex governs the 'internal state', or inward-directed thinking, helps process emotions and retrieve memories.

Amanda Chatel, a New Yorker who was a victim of date rape, is pushing for 'yes means yes' sex contracts to become mandatory on college campuses across the country. The 'yes means yes' law, which defines consent as 'affirmative, conscious, and voluntary agreement to engage in sexual activity' from each partner. The animals have multiplied to over 3,000 or 4,000 and are threatening to over-run the natural species in the lake. They are now considering two options - electroshocking the fish or draining the lake completely.

A Washington, DC-based company called United Space Structures wants to create a new space station. Their giant cylinder could apparently replace the ISS. It would rotate four times per minute to create artificial gravity. It would be 1,300ft (400 metres) long, cost £200 billion ($300 billion) and take 30 years to build. The dome-shaped structure would spin in one direction, and the top dome-shaped section would spin in the other direction. This would allow spacecraft to dock with the station, which would appear stationary to them.

The 51-year-old uses a modified microscope and camera to capture the detail of the butterfly's wing pattern. Butterfly wings are covered by thousands of microscopic scales split into two to three layers. Each scales is pigmented with melanins that give butterflies black and brown colouring.

Norwich scientists have developed an adaptor for colour blindness. Eye2TV can be plugged into any HDMI port on a TV or a computer monitor. A remote control or app then adjusts the colour adjustment. It allows colour blind people to watch shows they otherwise couldn't. The team from the University of East Anglia in Norwich is seeking £100,000 ($150,000) of funding to get their project of the ground.

Researchers from Goldsmiths University of London and Ohio State University studied more than 13,000 twins aged nine to 16. In 84 days from November 2013 to January 2014, the area around Azle, Texas, shook with 27 magnitude two or greater earthquakes. Now scientists believe these earthquakes were the result of high-pressure pressure injection of drilling wastewater into the ground. The oil and gas industry uses injection wells to get rid of wastewater, which can be chemicals, heavy metals, salt and radioactive material.

The USS Oklahoma capsized after being hit by nine torpedoes during the December 7, 1941, Japanese forces' surprise attack on Pearl Harbor. Altogether, 429 sailors and Marines onboard were killed, but only 35 were identified in the years immediately after. Hundreds were buried as unknowns at cemeteries in Hawaii, and were reburied as unknowns in 1950. The move is apparently a part of a new Pentagon policy on disinterring the remains of unknowns.

Spanish researchers say climate change impacted human migration. Until 1.4 million years ago it was too cold to inhabit southeast Spain. But then the climate warmed to 13°C (55°F) and became more humid. This enabled hominins - our distant ancestors. - to move to new regions. And it is thought that the earliest humans were a'slow-moving' species.

The study was conducted by scientists at Purdue University in Indiana. They were investigating how to reduce bird to aircraft collisions by keeping birds away from planes. Research showed that birds responded most to blue lights on planes. But when the lights were on, their response slowed. And they only became more alert when the lights were pulsing. This could help to capture birds' attention before an aircraft takes off.

The Maglev train completed a test run on a track in Yamanashi, Japan. It beat the previous record of 361mph (580km/h) set in 2003. Another attempt is scheduled for tomorrow, and engineers predict it could reach 373mph. Maglev trains use magnets to lift the carriages above the track. This eliminates the need for wheels and therefore any incidence of friction.

Deep water gas hydrates in the Arctic are reservoirs for abiotic methane. The gas forms through a process called serpentinisation. It occurs when seawater reacts with hot mantle rocks exhumed along large faults within the seafloor. The reservoirs are secure, and scientists don't believe they will impact climate change. Instead, they say similar formations could someday be used to store methane.

Neuroscientists at John Hopkins Medical School in Baltimore found that people with damage to the right sagittal stratum were far poorer than healthy people at detecting sarcasm. The right sagittal stratum is a bundle of white matter that lies between the cerebral cortex and subcortical structures in the brain. It is thought that this area of the brain is the key to detecting sarcasm.

University of Illinois scientists have created the first 3D simulation of merging black holes in a disk. It shows what happens when two supermassive black holes collide. The simulation was led by Dr Roman Gold and Dr Vasileios Paschalidis. They used Einstein's general theory of relativity to make the simulation. The results were used to predict how two supermassive black holes collide. And the prediction can be tested in real life by a new experiment.

Security researchers have found a way to intercept a person's fingerprints. The flaw lies in older versions of the Android operating system. Once a hacker has access to the kernel they can monitor all data sent to and from the phone. When a fingerprint is scanned it is encrypted and stored in a secure folder. But the flaw allows them to collect scans from the fingerprint sensor before it is encrypted. This means they can intercept scans from the sensor before being encrypted.

Scientists in Colorado have found evidence for a new solar season season. Every two years it appears 'bands' of magnetic field move to the surface. This combines with the existing 11-year solar cycle, causing even more powerful coronal mass ejections. The changes are caused by twisted, ring-shaped 'bands' of magnetic fields. These 'bands' of magnetic fields' rise from the solar interior. They are 'like Earth's jet stream,' say the scientists.

The Grimes Cottage is one of the oldest surviving homes in Sydney's harbourside suburb of Millers Point. The home was built by whaling captain George Grimes who constructed a row of early 1840s terraces depicted in artist Conrad Marten's work in 1843. The 416sqm inner city block property has a large northerly garden with footsteps down to the heart of the historic area of The Rocks. The property has a formal lounge and dining room with original fireplaces, high ceilings and an open-plan kitchen

WWF identified 11 'deforestation fronts' where 80 per cent of projected global forest losses by 2030. The areas are the Amazon, the Atlantic Forest and Gran Chaco, the Choco-Darien, the Congo Basin, East Africa, eastern Australia, the Greater Mekong in South East Asia, Borneo, New Guinea and Sumatra. The fronts are home to indigenous communities and endangered species such as orangutans and tigers.
